    • removeTrailingNewLines

      @Contract("_ -> param1") public static StringBuilder removeTrailingNewLines(StringBuilder sb)
      Removes all trailing new lines from a StringBuilder.
      Parameters:
      sb - The StringBuilder to remove the trailing new lines from.

      This object is modified in place.

      If the StringBuilder is empty or does not end with a new line, nothing is done.

      Returns:
      The StringBuilder for chaining.

    • removeTrailingNewLines

      public static String removeTrailingNewLines(CharSequence string)
      Removes all trailing new lines from a String.
      Parameters:
      string - The String to remove the trailing new lines from.

      If the String is empty or does not end with a new line, the same object is returned.

      Returns:
      The String without trailing new lines.

      Parameters:

      Returns:
      The same string that it received as input, but with a capizalized first letter.

    • isValidStructureName

      public static boolean isValidStructureName(@Nullable @Nullable String name)
      Check if a given string is a valid structure name. The following input is not allowed:
      • Numerical names (numerical values are reserved for UIDs).
      • Empty input.
      • Input containing spaces.
      Parameters:
      name - The name to test for validity,
      Returns:
      True if the name is allowed.

    • formatCollection

      public static <T> String formatCollection(Collection<T> collection, Function<T,String> mapper, int indent)
      Formats a collection of objects into a string.

      The objects are formatted using the provided mapper function. The resulting strings are joined with a delimiter and indented by the provided amount.

      For example, given a collection of Strings ["A", "B", "C"], a mapper that returns the input string, and an indent of 0, the resulting string would be: 

      
 - A
 - B
 - C

      Note that there is no trailing delimiter or new line.

      Type Parameters:
      T - The type of the objects in the collection.
      Parameters:
      collection - The collection of objects to format.
      mapper - The function to map the objects to strings.
      indent - The amount of spaces to indent the lines. This is the number of spaces before each '-'.
      Returns:
      A formatted string.

    • formatCollection

      public static <T> String formatCollection(Collection<T> collection, Function<T,String> mapper)
      Formats a collection of objects into a string.

      This method is a shortcut for formatCollection(Collection, Function, int) with an indent of 0.

      Type Parameters:
      T - The type of the objects in the collection.
      Parameters:
      collection - The collection of objects to format.
      mapper - The function to map the objects to strings.
      Returns:
      A formatted string.

    • formatCollection

      public static String formatCollection(Collection<?> collection, int indent)
      Formats a collection of objects into a string.

      This method is a shortcut for formatCollection(Collection, Function, int) with a mapper that calls Object.toString().

      Parameters:
      collection - The collection of objects to format.
      Returns:
      A formatted string.

    • formatCollection

      public static String formatCollection(Collection<?> collection)
      Formats a collection of objects into a string.

      This method is a shortcut for formatCollection(Collection, Function, int) with an indent of 0 and the mapper that calls Object.toString().

      Parameters:
      collection - The collection of objects to format.
      Returns:
      A formatted string.

    • stringCollector

      public static Collector<String,?,String> stringCollector(String delimiter, String emptyString)
      Creates a collector that collects a stream of strings into a formatted string.

      For example, given a delimiter of "\n - " and an empty String of "{}", and a stream with values "1", "2", and "3", the resulting string would be: 

      
 - 1
 - 2
 - 3

      Given the same delimiter and empty string, but an empty stream, the resulting string would be: 

      {}

      Note that there is no trailing delimiter or new line.

      Example usage: 

      
 List<String> list = List.of("1", "2", "3");
 String formatted = list.stream().collect(StringUtil.stringCollector("\n  - ", "{}"));
      Parameters:
      delimiter - The delimiter to prepend to each string in the stream.
      emptyString - The string representation when the stream is empty.
      Returns:
      A collector that collects the stream into a formatted string.

    • stringCollector

      public static Collector<String,?,String> stringCollector(String delimiter)
      Creates a collector that collects a stream of strings into a formatted string.

      This method is a shortcut for stringCollector(String, String) with the empty string "{}".

      Parameters:
      delimiter - The delimiter to prepend to each string in the stream.
      Returns:
      A collector that collects the stream into a formatted string.

    • stringCollector

      public static Collector<String,?,String> stringCollector()
      Creates a collector that collects a stream of strings into a formatted string.

      This method is a shortcut for stringCollector(String, String) with the empty string "{}" and the delimiter "\n- ".

      Returns:
      A collector that collects the stream into a formatted string.

    • getVariableIndices

      public static it.unimi.dsi.fastutil.ints.IntImmutableList getVariableIndices(String string, char variable)
      Gets all indices of a given character in a string.

      For example, given the string "Hello, World!" and the character 'o', this method would return the list [4, 8].

      Parameters:
      string - The string to search in.
      Returns:
      A list of all indices of the given character in the string.
